I've gone from SLC (near my home) to one of the little bumps in the road in Iowa to visit a friend (is it a visit if the friend was dying of cancer and the trip was to say goodbye?). The trip out is one of my fondest memories. The trip back is an absolute blurr.

I've also ridden the other direction, from SLC to Emeryville. Of the two I'd say going from SLC to Denver, and really from Grand Junction to Denver is the best part of the trip. It was late October, and the autumn leaves were just past their prime. It was a fantastic time to go. The only down side was pulling into Denver after dark.

Some tips for the trip. First, if you're in coach overnight you want to travel alone. You'll get two seats together if you're with someone, so sleeping across two seats isn't possible. I had brought a (now old school) Therm-A-Rest backpacking mattress to sleep on at my destination. I hadn't thought to use it as a seat cushion when I packed it, but I loaned it to an older couple who was spending their second night on the train and they said it saved them. I sat and slept on it in my seat the entire trip back from Iowa. The seats are fine on their own, but that air mattress made them feel first class.

I packed cup o noodles and oatmeal to eat. I brought a cup to prep the oatmeal. Downstairs in the club car/observation car there's a place to get boiling hot water. I tipped the attendant $1 each time they got me some hot water. I carried it back to my seat in a big refillable soda mug, but now I'd probably pack a HydroFlask for that purpose. It was nice to have a quart of boiling hot water at my seat.

If I were traveling this route for pleasure (and if I wasn't from the SLC area) I'd get off the train and spend 24 or more hours in a couple of places. I'd definitely get off in SLC. There's so much to see and do. Just be sure to get a car service to take you to your accommodations. The station is safe, but the area around it is pretty bad, and I say that after living in a bad part of Brooklyn.

My next place to spend a day is Glenwood Springs. Bring your swimming suit. The attraction is the hot springs.

Denver deserves at least 24 hours. The train station is right next to the baseball field. Plan your trip and catch a Rockies game. The restaurant scene near the station is fantastic. Heck, even if you're just passing through on the train call ahead and order something to go. The train stops long enough to slip into a nearby restaurant to grab your meal.

There's really nothing of note between Denver and Chicago. That said I'd think that Chicago would be worthy of a day or two of exploring. Like I said, the farthest east I've been on Amtrak is Iowa, but I've lived in NYC, so I know a big city like Chicago is worth your time.

If I added two more places to stop I'd include Truckee, CA and Grand Junction, CO. Truckee looked fun and touristy when I passed through. Grand Junction looks crappy from the railroad tracks, but it has some nice scenery nearby. Colorado National Monument is worth a visit. The best restaurants are in nearby Fruita. The Hot Tomato has amazing pizza and El Tapatio has great chipotle cream sauce.

Edit: I almost forgot, there are plans for a new excursion train to run from the Amtrak route south to Moab, Utah. I hope it works out because taking the train to Moab would be fantastic.

Note that the next passenger is several feet behind her, so there's obviously no real need for her to hurry; and note the high, artificial, pseudo-theatrical way in which the conductor says "Come on, you're holdin' up the line, we all want to get outta here, yeahh!": he's not actually being authoritarian, but rather is making fun of himself as an authority figure and taking the opportunity to joke around with a very charismatic passenger (who he was probably a bit smitten by, as just about any red-blooded hetero male would be).

I just did 46 hours (2 sleeps) on Amtrak coach and here are my tips.

1) Brush your teeth, wash your parts, and redo your deodorant every morning. It's critical.
2) Learn how to sleep on your back in advance.
3) Spend time outside of your seat. That means dining car, observation car, snack level. Walk downstairs and stand at the emergency exits. You can EASILY walk a mile a day in a train if you're up and moving around.
4) Step out at every smoke break even if you don't smoke.
5) Try to meet someone getting off at the next layover and ask them where the food is if they are a local. Or ask the Amtrak employees at the stop. There are hidden gems around the station that are folklore. People will know about them.
6) Wear merino wool or SilverAir athletic clothing.
7) Bring a fresh pair of socks for each morning you'll be on the train.
8) Track your progress with GPS on a phone. Waking up in a new state is super cool and boosts morale.
9) Find the big bathrooms for morning routines. IF it's the handicapped bathroom just be quick so you aren't causing problems.

The boarding passes are comparable in price, maybe slightly more expensive to ride the Train, (it costs $40 on a Greyhound from Seattle to Salem Oregon. 220 miles. And about $5 to $10 more on Amtrak.) but worth EVERY extra dollar.

As an experienced Amtrak rider (been on these trains 100s of times) some additional notes worth pointing out if your considering traveling this way:


1) Almost every double decker Amtrak Superliner coach I've been on has a larger lavatory meant specifically for changing. They're much larger rooms that contain a seat and a mirror in addition to the sink/toilet. There's one at the end of the hall in the lower level, and one usually to the side. There's also almost always larger handicapped rest room if that fails. If for whatever reason the restrooms in your coach aren't cutting it, go to the next coach.


2). Eva forgot to point out that the coach seats also almost always have fold out leg extenders and footrests which can improve your sleeping surface area if you sleep diagonal (provided you don't have a neighbor sitting next to you. There are two levers: one reclines the seat back, the other releases the leg extender which you will then have to physically pull up. The footrests extend downward from the seat in front of you.


3). There are FIVE classes on Amtrak. Coach / Roomette (upper and lower sections) / Family Bedroom (lower section only) / Bedroom (upper sections only) / Handicapped Bedroom (lower section only).


Coach is typically for people taking short legs along the cross-country route.


Roomettes (Eva showed one of the lower level ones) are the best value because your diner car meals are free and you have the use of shared showers. They are small. It does bunk but it's not the most comfortable space for two larger people.


Family bedrooms (Eva showed one) can sleep a family of 4, they are the largest rooms extending the full width of the train but are not as nicely appointed as the standard Bedrooms, they're also only on the lower levels. Meals are free.

Bedrooms are nice but expensive all found on the upper level. You get a bigger sleeping area, chair, more room plus your own toilet/shower room. Some bedrooms can conjoin allowing families or friends to create a larger space. Meals are free.


Handicapped bedrooms are large specifically made for someone with limited mobility. They extend the full width of the train and have a large bathroom without a shower to one side. Meals are free.


4). Traveling east of Chicago, you'll always be on trains that are single story. This is because most of the eastern cities are older and have tunnels/bridges that cannot accommodate taller cars. So some of the amenities change slightly with the east coast trains, like the roomettes are actually nicer in the single story trains (having two windows, one for the upper bunk and a toilet/sink).


Good luck!

Yes, there are a lot of rude and lazy Amtrak employees, especially in New York State, and they're a curse on the company and I've often gotten on their case when I've run into them as a passenger; but if you listen carefully to the tone and rhythm of this conductor's voice and look at the expression on his face, it seems pretty clear that he isn't being rude: rather, he's enjoying her vlogging delivery (I think that's him laughing appreciatively in the background after she says "Guys, this feels slightly surreal"), and is just good-naturedly kidding her about the awkwardness of her rolling a suitcase, recording a video for an audience, and exiting the train car all at the same time; and she seems to get the joke and to be going along with it. Note that the next passenger is several feet behind her, so there's obviously no real need for her to hurry; and note the high, artificial, pseudo-theatrical way in which the conductor says "Come on, you're holdin' up the line, we all want to get outta here, yeahh!": he's not actually being authoritarian, but rather is making fun of himself as an authority figure and taking the opportunity to joke around with a very charismatic passenger (who he was probably a bit smitten by, as just about any red-blooded hetero male would be).

That said, the light-hearted nature of this interchange is a bit too subtle to come across clearly in the video, and arguably should've been edited out for that reason.
